Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing the Book "Coloring the Universe" to Serve Undergraduate Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator and coauthors Kimberly Arcand and Megan Watzke are writing "Coloring the Universe," a book that will provide a behind-the-scenes look at how color astronomical images are made by professional observatories. There are a number of coffee table books showcasing beautiful astronomical images, but none of them focus on how the images are made (astrophotography). Books that do describe image-making techniques are primarily "how to" books intended for amateur astronomers and do not describe the underlying science. "Coloring the Universe" will explain how color-composite images are made, how they are used by scientists for visualization purposes, and how they are shared with the public to highlight new scientific discoveries. The book will also be unique in featuring primarily NSF-funded telescopes and the images made with them. Support from this grant will allow the authors to enhance the book so that it will be more useful as a teaching tool at the undergraduate level. They will add content that provides more information and examples, and they will create a Web site that contains image-making tutorials, data from telescopes with which students can make their own images, and an image gallery allowing students and the public to share their work.

Astronomical images offer an engaging introduction to important topics in astronomy, such as how telescopes and charge-coupled devices (CCDs) work, narrowband filters, and multi-wavelength imaging. Many colleges that have access to small-aperture telescopes and CCD cameras have laboratory exercises in which astronomy students make images of astronomical objects. These labs serve as an important tool for teaching how telescopes and CCDs work, while doing it in a fun, visually appealing way. With its enhanced content, "Coloring the Universe" will be a valuable resource for teaching not only how the professionals make images, but why scientists make them the way they do. The tutorials on the Web site will be incorporated into introductory astronomy classes at the University of Alaska Anchorage and will also be presented to instructors in astronomy education groups, such as the Research-Based Science Education (RBSE) group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Astronomy has long been a gateway to exciting students and the public about science.  Much of this enthusiasm is driven by color astronomical images from professional observatories such as NASA's Hubble Space Telescope and the NSF's Gemini Observatory and Kitt Peak National Observatory (KPNO).  These images regularly appear in the national news and on websites such as NASA's Astronomy Picture of the Day (APOD).


These images also often invite skepticism.  People frequently ask questions such as, "Is this what it really looks like?" and "Are the colors real?"  In an age of computer graphics and digital image manipulation (i.e., "Photoshopping"), people want assurances about the images they see.  While the first question above is easy to answer- yes, these are real pictures of real objects- the other question is more complex and requires a deeper understanding of how we see and how astronomical images are made.


These questions are what inspired the PI (and his co-authors) to write a book called "Coloring the Universe."  Over the years there have been many "coffee table"-style books of astronomical images.  But none of them have focused on how the images are made.  Books that do describe image-making techniques are primarily "how to" books intended for amateur astronomers and do not describe the science behind them.  Coloring the Universe explains how color-composite images are made, how they are used by scientists for visualization purposes, and how they are used to highlight new scientific discoveries.  This book is also unique in that it features primarily NSF telescopes and the images made with them.


The purpose of this grant was to enable the authors to (1) add content to the book that will provide more information and examples, so that it will be useful for college-level teaching (while also making the book more interesting to the public); and (2) to create a website that contains image-making tutorials, along with data from KPNO telescopes with which students can make their own images.


With the support of the NSF we were able to add to the book: (1) A new chapter, called "Color is Knowledge," that explains how scientists interpret the color in stars, gas, and galaxies to learn about these objects.  (2) More detail on the techniques used to create images; e.g., how transfer functions are used to convert FITS data files into grayscale TIFF images. (3) Examples where we show the images from each filter in their assigned colors before combining them to make the final color composite image.  We will explain how and why each color was chosen. (4) More examples and details on how astronomers use narrowband filters to study different kinds of objects (e.g., Herbig-Haro outflows) and the science they learn about them. (5) The history of NSF facilities profiled in the book (Gemini, NOAO, and NRAO), including their origins as well as the NSF philosophy of enabling access for everyone to world-class research facilities. (6) Details about how astronomers get to use these telescopes, including how time is allocated and how observations are completed (e.g., classical and queue observing). (7) Additional design elements, including sidebars of supplementary information, a glossary of terms, and an index will be added so that students can find information more readily.


The book is sold within the United States by the University of Alaska Press, which has made a commitment to keep the book in print in perpetuity.  Released in November 2015, the initial print run of 2000 books quickly sold out and another run of 2000 books was completed in March 2016.  The book has received high praise in many reviews; e.g., from BBC's Sky at Night, Astronomy magazine, Sky & Telescope, and Forbes.


As part of the NSF grant we also created tutorials to teach undergraduates the techniques behind making color images. The tutorials can be found here:


http://rbseu.uaa.alaska.edu/projects/imagemaking/index.html


These were instead put online so that they can be updated as new software becomes available. The tutorials take students through the step-by-step process of making a color image (e.g., converting FITS datafiles into TIFF grayscale images, “colorizing” the grayscale images, and stacking them to create the final color composite image). 


The website also hosts the datasets necessary for the tutorials.  Imaging data from the KPNO/WIYN 0.9-meter telescope are included for about thirty astronomical objects.  Students are encouraged to post their images to social media (e.g., Instagram) with the hashtag #colortheuniverse.


The tutorials have been incorporated into the introductory astronomy classes at UAA, as well as presented to instructors in the RBSE and “astrolrnr” educational groups. The book has already been adopted by Indiana University which used it to teach a class called "The Art of Astronomy" to 150 students.  The class will be taught again in Summer 2016 to 120 students.
